title_sort: peter doyle to walt whitman, 1 october [1868]
title: Peter Doyle to Walt Whitman, 1 October [1868]
text: 1868WashingtonOct 1stDear WaltI received your letter of the 29th yesterday the 30th inst & was very glad to hear you was doing so well I am happy to state that I am well & doing well in fact everything is doing firstrate[first rate] at present we have had quite a little alteration in R. R. matters since i[I] wrote last which got the boys up to the highest pitch of excitement Mr Dunning has resigned his position as President of the Road & Mr Riker also of New york[York] has taken his place I expect you will remmember[remember] Riker as being President of the Road for a short time before they have also Issued[issued] new rates in regard to carrying Baggage[baggage] & Market Baskets[market baskets] hereafter it will be as follows for a large trunk 4. fares middlen size 3. fares small one 2 fares for a large market basket 2 fares small one 1 fare for a small Valise[valise] 1 fare so you see we have a lively time with the Passengers carrying out such rules. you remember when you went away that at about the same time Mr Noyes went away on a pleasant trip he has wrote several letters for the Star which i[I] expect you have noticed you will find an interesting letter in Wednesday paper which i[I] sent you it is about chicago[Chicago] I see today that several of the Departments which has been stopping work at 3 o clock has commenced to work until 4 o'clockI showed your letter to Jimmy Sorrill & it tickled his very much as he did not know that i[I] told you what he said about that young lady. he sends his best love I also reminded you Pastie to Tom Hassett & it pleased him very much he also sends his best love. Dave Henry Hunt & the Californian & Towers & all the rest of the boys sends love & best respects to you we have had some splendid weather for 3. or 4 days but it is clouding up today & i[I] expect more wet weather. I hear that the Rickings opera troupe is playing to very good Houses i[I] have not been to see them yetGen. Frank Blair has been here this week but the Democracy did not turn out as they usually do when some big fellow arrives I expect you will get tired of so much scribbling as its done with a lead pencil & very often in the caryours trulyPete Peter Doyle to Walt Whitman, 1 October [1868]
